title: Building and Securing a Small Network
description: Network troubleshooting, baseline establishment, and diagnostic tools

keyConcepts.title: Network Troubleshooting Tools
keyConcepts.description: Essential utilities for diagnosing network issues: ping (tests connectivity), tracert/traceroute (shows path), show commands (displays configuration and status), CDP (discovers neighbors), nslookup (DNS resolution).

keyConcepts.title: Network Baseline
keyConcepts.description: Documentation of normal network performance established at regular intervals over time. Used to identify latency issues by comparing current ping response times against historical data.

keyConcepts.title: Protocol Analyzer
keyConcepts.description: Tool that captures and analyzes network traffic patterns on each segment. Used during upgrade planning to document traffic requirements and determine capacity needs.

keyConcepts.title: Structured Troubleshooting Methodology
keyConcepts.description: Systematic approach: (1) Identify problem, (2) Establish theory of probable causes, (3) Test theory, (4) Establish plan of action, (5) Implement solution, (6) Verify functionality, (7) Document.

keyConcepts.title: Cisco IOS Show Commands
keyConcepts.description: Essential diagnostic commands: show ip interface brief (IP summary), show interfaces (detailed Layer 1/2 info), show ip route (routing table), show cdp neighbors (Layer 2 discovery), show running-config (active config).

keyConcepts.title: Extended Ping
keyConcepts.description: Advanced ping mode accessed by issuing ping without destination in privileged EXEC mode. Allows specifying source interface for testing specific network paths.

importantPoints: Network baseline should be established at regular intervals over time
Increased ping response times indicate latency issues
Protocol analyzers document traffic for capacity planning
Voice and video are real-time, delay-sensitive applications
Redundancy eliminates single points of failure (multiple paths)
True redundancy requires second router AND second ISP
APIPA range 169.254.0.0/16 indicates DHCP server unreachable
Can reach by IP but not name = DNS issue
Debug output sent to console line by default
Use 'terminal monitor' to see debug on VTY/Telnet sessions
Ping symbols: ! = success, . = timeout, U = unreachable
tracert (Windows) / traceroute (Linux) shows each hop
tracert -6 forces IPv6 trace
show ip interface brief: IP addresses and up/down status
show interfaces: duplex, speed, error details (Layer 1/2)
show ip route: routing table and exit interfaces
show cdp neighbors: verifies Layer 2 connectivity
show cdp neighbors detail: IP, hostname, IOS version
show version: configuration register value
show running-config: active device configuration
CDP can be disabled globally or per-interface
CDP operates at Layer 2 (no Layer 3 required)
Extended ping: issue ping with no destination in priv EXEC
nslookup: DNS name resolution testing
ipconfig: Windows PC network info
ipconfig getifaddr [interface]: Mac IP info
show ipv6 interface: IPv6 interface details
Failed ping doesn't guarantee problem - could be ICMP blocked
Structured approach ends with documentation

quickReference.label: Redundancy Definition
quickReference.value: Multiple paths, no single failure point
